title: Monday, 14th January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Okay, this again. Hello. Morning.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
BornCynic Morning
Soundbuy Hello
BE11:07am

Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc. Unsure where to begin, but that's not unusual.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Stobart/Flybe nonsense?
VV75 morning
MassimoJ morning
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Moaning!

We're down. China.

Lemmy Ophir was amusing on Friday too, a sort of Dutch auction
11:08 am
BE11:09am

China said exports in December fell 4.4 per cent year on year, the largest since the end of 2016 and lower than estimates.

Playing FTSE Morning - JD Sports making for a positive start to the week in Retail

Annual export growth was 9.9 per cent year on year in dollar terms, figures released on Monday showed.

BE11:09am

https://www.ft.com...-9e64-d150b3105d21

Playing FTSE Best thing about China data is Trade Surplus with US has actually grown.

BE11:10am

https://www.market...rtfolio-2018-12-06

red @Playing FTSEthat is down to inventory stacking ahead of tariffs

11:11 am
BE11:11am

In short, they scanned Bloomberg market wraps, subtracted the days in which stock market falls were getting the blame for declines, and used that to calculate the effect of the uncertainty.

FATDAZ Morning all
BE11:12am

Which is a pretty fundamental misunderstanding of how market reporting works. THE EXPLANATIONS ARE REVERSE ENGINEERED, PEOPLE.

Manxish Morning everyone
red yes sometimes explainations and reports are changed midday if sentiment swings and prices reverse

Anyway, let me see if there's any China macro grey to point out that export growth was still the best since 2011.

11:14 am

..... nope, there isn't. You're on your own. Sorry. It's Monday.

undefined

BE11:15am

And onto corporate. JD Sports mentioned.

11:15 am
JD Sports Fashion PLC (JD.:LSE): Last: 431.05, up 34.85 (+8.80%), High: 440.50, Low: 412.20, Volume: 1.67m
BE11:15am

(@Fatdaz: no ta.)

Lemmy There was an AV podcast with Robert Shiller on market "narratives"
Excel Developer Found a free economics calendar with the China data scheduled, https://tradingeconomics.com/china/calendar
BE11:17am

Still the acceptable face of retail, because it's totally reliant on getting priority supply from a couple of big companies over which it has zero leverage.

FATDAZ @BE :)
11:17 am
BE11:17am

It's working now. Just as it did for the phone shops a decade or so ago.

BE11:18am

Anyway, Morgan Stanley can summarise.

BE11:18am

JD Sports had not reported to the market since September, so there is a good deal of 'new news' in trading here. It issued a short statement with two key
figures: LFL sales over the last 48 weeks and guidance for the FY 2018/19 profit outcome.
- LFL sales over the 48 weeks in the Sports Fashion fascias, excluding Finish Line and Sport Zone, have come in at more than+5% (with total sales growth in these fascias of +15%). It is not clear where consensus was on these figures, and we have not been given a total group sales growth figure.
- Management stated that it is confident the full-year Profit Before Tax outcome for FY 2018/19 will come in at the higher end of the consensus range: £325m to £352m. Current consensus, according to Bloomberg, is at £344m, and therefore the upper end of expectations is c.2% above that figure.

red portion of JD clients are recession proof
11:18 am
BE11:19am

With regards to Finish Line, JD Sports commented "It is too early to draw any conclusions from the early performance of JD in the United States although we are encouraged by the developments to date". It plans to convert up to a further 15 stores in the US to JD in FYH1 2019/20. It also stated that it is pleased with the development wider Finish Line business. However, we have not been given a figure on the performance of Finish Line.
- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but as the statement makes clear, we may see small upgrades today. According to Bloomberg, consensus is looking for JD Sports to deliver FY 2018/19 Pre Tax Profits of £344 million (giving EPS of 27.5p).
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, JD Sports is trading on 13.0x calendarised 2019 earnings, 7.2x EBITDA, with a 0.5% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 11.0x, 7.0x and 4.2%, respectively.

BE11:19am

(@Red: why?)

BE11:19am

And Peel Hunt.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

JD Sports has delivered a –quite frankly – excellent trading update, with LFL accelerating across the globe. The UK’s performance (inc online) is LFL positive, but the real eyecatchers are Europe (where in-store LFL is double-digit) and in the US, where LFL is c5% and gross margins are handily ahead. Forecasts must rise (held back a bit by some extra cost of the DC overhaul), and this is a great example of the fact that retail conditions are not impossible for a retailer with the right product and a proximity to its customers. 13x PE really is a steal. BUY.

red a lot of almost b2b old fashioned cash sales
Blackbag99 I suppose the glamping and ski set. I am not sure how much that insulates them though
Soundbuy JD sports Bristol..........average age about 16 on a Saturday.........its parents trying to prise their kids off the Xbox with the promise of a new pair of trainers.....
BE11:20am

Have you ever tried to buy a pair of trainers there, by the way? It's a deeply crappy system.

BE11:21am

You find what you want in the wall, flag down one of the floor assistants who show the kind of enthusiasm you'd expect of someone dealing with teenagers all day while earning minimum wage .....

11:21 am
BE11:21am

... and get them to request your kicks from the backroom.

BE11:23am

Five to 15 minutes later, the name of your trainers -- Nike Air Force 1 combo colourway Size 10.5 -- appear on a screen above the floor.

FATDAZ @BE do have head sets on ?
FATDAZ do they have headsets on?

Deep Breath everyone... @BE - you are doing this in real time!
BE11:23am

And there might or might not be a stockroom person wandering through the shopfloor at the same time. You might or might not be able to spot the stockroom person as they wander.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

If you don't, they return to the stockroom and you have to try again.

BE11:24am

It's amazing and terrible.

Soundbuy @ casapinos - waste of time.....vast variations between and within brands..

And that's your star of UK retail these days. Here's Barclays.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Reports from several UK retailers suggest that November was challenging, and although December appears to have been better, the overall tone has been quite negative since JD Sports last reported in September. Indeed, many retailers have issued profit warnings since JD’s last update. In this environment, we think JD’s performance stands out; we view it as a reflection of the company’s differentiated product offering, benefits of growing scale, and strong management.

undefined

BE11:25am

While on retail, good note from Credit Suisse on Next.

11:25 am
Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,601, down 156 (-3.28%), High: 4,695, Low: 4,592, Volume: 336.27k
BE11:26am

Gist is as you'd expect. Structural decline, high street dying .....

BE11:27am

Makes the usual arguments about how peer closures hit footfall through Next's marginal stores, resulting in deeper margin attrition as the closures accelerate.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The credit book is only really mentioned in passing, but it's worth highlighting.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
wayneJ Possibly Next facing to the reality that its customers have run out of capacity for credit?
BE11:28am

The 80% increase in the £1.2bn credit book over 5Y has come on a declining number of credit account holders, so the average balance per account has doubled to £485, and the overall credit book is equivalent to 73% of Directory annual sales. In the meantime the average gross yield on the book has gradually declined from 26% to 21.9%, as APR’s have declined, but it still remains high given that customers effectively get 6 weeks of free credit, and many will then repay immediately. Declining yields were offset by low bad debt charges, which are now starting to increase again. Next is currently trialing its new 3 step credit offer (3 month free credit) to appeal to a younger customer and we can see the appeal in terms of driving sales. We are less convinced in how many will convert to interest-paying customers at the end of the period, so at best we assume it continues to put pressure on yields.

BE11:29am

So credit balances per account of £485!

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Which, CS argues, looks pretty maxed out.

Blackbag99 £485 doesn't buy much furniture
wayneJ If a substanial % of Next clients repay at the end of the interest free period it suggests that (i) the interest paying customers might have a lot more than £485 of credit balance (ii) is the APR calculated including or excluding the interest free period?
BE11:30am

(@Blackbag: indeed. Often wondered how much of the Next credit book is furniture, which seems pretty expensive compared with elsewhere.)

BE11:30am

Otherwise, you have FX looking less favourable for buying from Indonesia or wherever.

wayneJ (iii) are sales staff incentivised to encourage customers to take credit? And is this nowadays entirely without risk from FCA review?

While the shares trade in line with UK peers on 11x 12m FWD PER, with 4Y EPS growth of 2.3% pa we see
little upside, given concerns over UK consumption and much better value
elsewhere in the sector in categories and stocks with structural growth, ie
online (Asos/Zalando), discount (B&M/Primark) and sporting goods
(Adidas/JD Sport).

cracklenpop 'JD Sports sell stuff you want at prices you can afford': my 16 year-old daughter this morning.

BE11:36am

Here's Stifel.

Lemmy Looking for a new job wayne? That pay rate is for under 25s
BE11:36am

We note this morning's rejection of the possible offer by Medco by Ophir and also want to say to Ophir shareholders: don't now sell this business for less than it is worth- or possibly, if a firm bid is made that isn't high enough, don't sell this business at all. We believe the material change that the Santos assets represent to the business is under-appreciated by the market, hence in our view the valuation disconnect between NAV and share price and PT Medco's takeover approach to take advantage of this. However, we also urge Ophir to lay out their vision- we believe there is substantial free cash flow from the assets, the company needs to explain how it will be reinvested and also distributed back to shareholdersWe revise our NAV to reflect the exploration success at Paus and the lower year end net debt. Our NAV and price target moves to 71p from previous 66p per share and we keep our buy recommendation.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

And GMP.

BE11:37am

We believe this could be a negotiating tactic from Medco with a compromise not too far from being met. Our ReNAV is only £0.51 per share. This offer represents a c. 8% premium to Friday’s close.

wayneJ Oh - I fear I will not be able to pass for under 25. Still seems a tad on the low side?
undefined

We've also got the EU reassuring on the backstop: https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

BE11:42am

Goldman has a Brexit Q&A. I'll try and pick out a few highlights.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

How likely is a second referendum? In our view, the probability of a second referendum has been rising, but it remains outside our base case.
With Parliament wresting the agenda-setting power away from the Prime Minister, we think the probability of “no Brexit” is rising, but remains moderate. A second referendum is not our base case because it remains unclear what Parliament will do with the agenda-setting power it is accumulating. Although the Prime Minister’s critics have begun to coalesce around their opposition to a “no deal” Brexit, those critics have so far proven unable to coalesce around a single, well-specified alternative. Only when MPs choose to table concrete amendments to the Prime Minister’s modified Brexit deal will it become clear whether any specific alternative can command a majority in Parliament. At this stage, we think there are too many Brexit outcomes still in play for an amendment in favour of a second referendum to command a majority. A pro-EU Conservative Party backbencher may deem Monday 21 January an opportune moment to test this view. It is more likely, however, that pro-EU MPs also opt to count down the clock, waiting for competing Brexit alternatives to be eliminated first.

Blackbag99 Does it change anything? No offence, but the EU was never annexing NI. I suppose the vassalage nutjobs might be happier
BE11:42am

What is the chance of an extension of the Article 50 deadline? Agreeing for more time beyond 29 March has become more likely, but the EU will wait for a clear request from the UK government.
Conditional on Parliament in the UK expressing a clear path towards legislating for a second referendum, we think the EU would agree to extend the 29 March deadline embedded in Article 50. If the will of Parliament is instead expressed as a desire for a slightly amended Brexit deal, we think the EU would also be willing to agree to a short extension, in order to create more time to take stock of negotiations. In a scenario in which Parliament has failed to coalesce around a well-specified alternative, we think the EU would be less willing to offer the UK more time, given the European Parliament elections (scheduled for 23-26 May).

BE11:42am

So is “no deal” off the table? Largely, but not entirely.
We think the probability of a “no deal” Brexit is low, and falling, but not zero. A “no deal” departure on 29 March is the default outcome if nothing else happens. But, in practice, a “no deal” exit would require an impasse in Parliament over every feasible alternative, as well as insistence by the EU that the existing Article 50 deadline cannot be extended. In particular, a “no deal” departure would require Parliament to turn down the option of unilaterally revoking Article 50: an option which is now clear in legal terms, even if still muddied in terms of political viability. In our view, co-ordination failure on such a scale looks unlikely given the large macro impact of a “no deal” scenario, but it is not impossible.

Maudise Do you think that no brexit is actually likely, or is a can-kick the more politically palatable thing to do?
wayneJ The 'new' Next 3 step programme has an APR of 29.9% if u miss a payment - https://www.next.co.uk/credit
red @Maudisebercow moves now allows MP's to go straight to revoking article 50.
11:43 am
BE11:44am

"We maintain our base case that Parliament will pave the way to a status quo post-Brexit transition phase, beginning at the end of March," concludes Goldman.

red its just a question if MP's can live with going against referendum vote. nothing more than that now.
Maudise What a time to be alive
BE11:44am

All of which is thrilling, of course, but how do you trade it? Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:45am

Post the 4Q sell-off in global stocks, UK equity absolute valuations have fallen to particularly low levels. For example, the trailing dividend yield for the median UK stock hit 4.3%, which represents the highest reading in nearly 25 years excluding 3Q08/1Q09.

LegalEagle ah I see Brexit is being discussed. Sorry I am late(!)

11:45 am
BE11:45am

They're overweight UK.

BE11:45am

Despite modest outperformance in 4Q, UK equity valuations still look very low relative to their global peers. For example, MSCI UK trades at a 30% discount to MSCI World (lowest since early 1990s) and a 12% discount to MSCI Europe (lowest since 2000).

wayneJ I was very concerned re the newspapers at the weekend frothing re 'coup' etc. I had not realised the govt had precedence in parliamentary business since the 1880s. But even there there are precedents for Parliament to override the govt as occurred in 1940 near the beginning of the war.
alewis2005 if corbyn would position himself as anti-brexit (which is a risk, so he'll never do it) then labour could wrap this whole thing up

There's not a lot in there to explain what positive and negative outcomes might be here, but this is the prediction anyway:

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Perceived 'positive' outcome: FTSE100 up 5%; FTSE250 up 10-15%; Domestic Banks up 25-30% and Real Estate stocks likely to be biggest beneficiaries;
Housebuilders and Retailers would also outperform.
Perceived 'negative' outcome: FTSE100 down 5%; FTSE250 down 15%; Domestic Banks down 25-30%. Pharmaceuticals, Staples, Tech and Commodity sectors likely to be relative outperformers.

Historically there has been a relationship between UK equities outperforming Eurozone equities when Sterling has weakened against the Euro. That relationship has broken down post the referendum (Figure 4) as UK equities have underperformed the Eurozone despite a weaker currency (GBP). However, weak Sterling has had a significant impact below the index level. For UK companies the geographic split of revenue between the UK and non UK has been a key factor for earnings (Figure 5), valuation (Figure 6) and performance (Figure 7) driven by the combination of risks around Brexit, weaker UK growth compared to the Eurozone (Figure 8) and the impact of a volatile currency.

Looking solely at larger and medium-sized producers under coverage, these companies are forecasted to hit a “peak gold production” in 2021. As larger companies are generally reluctant to become smaller companies, we have assumed that larger and medium-sized producers are the most likely to add to their asset portfolio through M&A in the near future.

BE12:02pm

Chevron is reported to be selling its UK North Sea portfolio, including a
19.4% stake in the Clair field, plus stakes in Alba, Captain, Elgin/Franklin,
Erskine and Jade as well as the Britannia platform and its satellites. It is
unclear if and how the package might be broken up, as potential buyers
including private (Chrysaor, INEOS, etc.) and public companies focus on
their core areas and strengths.
Premier is an established UK operator with a sizeable operation in
Aberdeen, and the acquisition of a package of producing assets would
enable it to unlock value tied up in its $4.1bn of UK tax losses and capital
allowances. Given these synergies any acquisitions at fair prices should
be value accretive. However, we would not expect management to put
its balance sheet at risk and/or issue shares at a material discount to the
current share price.
With oil prices having gyrated since Chevron commenced its
rationalisation process last year, the outlook for the seller and the
attitudes of the potential (competing) bidders may have hardened. We
understand that the sale process is still in its early stages, and with all
attention currently fixed on Chevron it would be worth considering what
other, lower profile, opportunities might exist.

BE12:03pm

We believe any sizeable deal by Premier would require a combination of debt and equity given one important rationale for the deal is likely to be reducing debt leverage. The company ended 2018 with a net debt to EBITDAX ratio of 3.0x and accounting net debt of $2.3bn.

BE12:04pm

Increasing Premier’s focus on the UK makes sense from the perspective of accelerating the use of its $4.1bn in UK tax losses. The sale of non-UK assets may be part of a plan to fund North Sea acquisitions, but we think time constraints mean it is unlikely to be part of the initial funding solution for the Chevron package.

We view the 25% stake in the Zama oil discovery on Block 7 offshore Mexico as Premier’s most marketable pre-development asset. We value the stake at ~$250m on a risked basis, with appraisal drilling ongoing. In December, DEA agreed to acquire licence partner Sierra Oil & Gas for ~$500m, which we estimate provides a mark-to-mark valuation of Premier’s stake of ~$300m.
